content.summary_text: The introduction of history trees has recently led to the development of optimal linear-time algorithms for anonymous dynamic networks. In Section 2, we outline the basic architecture of history tree, drawing comparisons with Yamashita-Kameda's views and Boldi-Vigna's minimum bases. We showcase a straightforward linear- time algorithm for dynamic networks that illustrates the practicality of history Trees. We discuss more advanced applications ofhistory trees in challenging network situations.

The view V t G (p) is defined as the portion of H G spanned by all directed paths from the root r to v, using black and red edges indifferently. This is done by a straightforward match-and-merge algorithm, starting from theRoot and proceeding level by level, as exemplified in Figure.

In Section 2.3 we gave a Counting algorithm for connected undirected dynamic networks with a unique leader that stabilizes in 2n -2 steps. In any non-branching level of the history tree of a strongly connected directed dynamic network with output port awareness, all nodes must have the same anonymity. We will give a universal self-stabilizing protocol that constructs coherent views.
